verses.text: I am the true vine, and my Father is the gardener.
verses.comment: Jesus uses the imagery of the vine, often representing Israel in the Old Testament, but now identifies Himself as the true and perfect vine. This is a profound claim of fulfilment and of His unique role as the source of divine life.

verses.text: Every branch in me that does not bear fruit, He removes; and every branch that does bear fruit, He prunes, so that it may bear more fruit.
verses.comment: God's active involvement in believers' lives encourages growth and holiness. The concept of pruning has a spiritual meaning—sometimes suffering and correction lead to deeper faith and virtue.

verses.text: You are already clean because of the word I have spoken to you.
verses.comment: Jesus’ word has a sanctifying power. Being made clean references spiritual purification, reminiscent of Old Testament purification rituals, now accomplished through Christ’s word.

verses.text: Remain in me, and I in you. Just as the branch cannot bear fruit by itself unless it remains in the vine, neither can you unless you remain in me.
verses.comment: Union with Christ is necessary for spiritual fruitfulness. This mutual indwelling is a key New Testament theme, suggesting a real spiritual communion with Christ.

verses.text: I am the vine; you are the branches. Whoever remains in me and I in him, he bears much fruit; for apart from me you can do nothing.
verses.comment: Jesus again emphasizes His indispensable role. Spiritual life and fruitful action are possible only in genuine, sustained union with Christ.

verses.text: If anyone does not remain in me, he is thrown away like a branch and withers; such branches are gathered, thrown into the fire, and burned.
verses.comment: Jesus warns of judgment for those who abandon communion with Him. The imagery of fire evokes eschatological judgment, often understood spiritually, but also in the context of eternal consequences.

verses.text: If you remain in me and my words remain in you, ask whatever you wish, and it will be done for you.
verses.comment: Intimate union with Christ transforms desires to align with God’s will, making prayer effective. The promise is conditional, emphasizing spiritual alignment.

verses.text: By this my Father is glorified: that you bear much fruit and show yourselves to be my disciples.
verses.comment: Fruitfulness in Christian life brings glory to God and evidences true discipleship. This links spiritual life to visible action.

verses.text: Just as the Father has loved me, so have I loved you; remain in my love.
verses.comment: Christ’s love for His followers mirrors the perfect love between Father and Son, implying a profound participation in divine life.

verses.text: If you keep my commandments, you will remain in my love, just as I have kept my Father's commandments and remain in His love.
verses.comment: Obedience is the pathway to remaining within Christ’s love—linking belief with moral action, echoing biblical calls to holiness.

verses.text: I have spoken these things to you so that my joy may be in you, and your joy may be complete.
verses.comment: True joy flows from communion with Christ, a joy that is both spiritual and communal, reaching fulfillment in union with God.

verses.text: This is my commandment: that you love one another, just as I have loved you.
verses.comment: Love is the supreme commandment—a call to imitate Christ’s sacrificial and unconditional love, foundational for Christian community life.

verses.text: Greater love has no one than this, that someone lay down his life for his friends.
verses.comment: Jesus anticipates his own sacrifice; self-giving love is the highest form. This verse has deep christological implications pointing toward the cross.

verses.text: You are my friends if you do what I command you.
verses.comment: Friendship with Christ includes obedience, reinforcing the personal yet respectful relationship believers are called to have with Him.

verses.text: I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know what his master is doing. But I have called you friends, for all that I have heard from my Father I have made known to you.
verses.comment: Jesus elevates the disciples’ status through intimate revelation, underscoring the new covenant and familial relationship with God.

verses.text: You did not choose me, but I chose you, and appointed you so that you should go and bear fruit and that your fruit should remain, so that whatever you ask the Father in my name, He may give it to you.
verses.comment: Emphasizes divine initiative in salvation and vocation, connecting spiritual fruit to a permanent, lasting reality and effective prayer.

verses.text: These things I command you, so that you love one another.
verses.comment: Reiterates the foundational command to love, which is central to Christian morality and the unity of believers.

verses.text: If the world hates you, know that it has hated me before it hated you.
verses.comment: Jesus prepares His followers for opposition, affirming identification with Him brings both suffering and dignity.

verses.text: If you were of the world, the world would love its own; but because you are not of the world, but I chose you out of the world, therefore the world hates you.
verses.comment: Highlights the fundamental difference between believers and the world system—chosen by Christ, set apart for holiness.

verses.text: Remember the word that I spoke to you: ‘A servant is not greater than his master.’ If they persecuted me, they will also persecute you; if they kept my word, they will keep yours.
verses.comment: Jesus sets expectations for discipleship, reminding them that following Him means sharing in both His sufferings and His mission.

verses.text: But all these things they will do to you on account of my name, because they do not know Him who sent me.
verses.comment: Persecution arises from spiritual blindness toward God the Father and rejection of Christ's divinity.

verses.text: If I had not come and spoken to them, they would not have sin; but now they have no excuse for their sin.
verses.comment: Jesus’ revelation brings responsibility; explicit rejection of Him removes the possibility of ignorance.

verses.text: Whoever hates me hates my Father also.
verses.comment: Rejection of Jesus is inseparable from rejection of God. The unity between Father and Son is clear—another claim to divinity.

verses.text: If I had not done among them the works that no one else did, they would not have sin. But now, they have seen and hated both me and my Father.
verses.comment: Miraculous signs are grounds for belief; persistent refusal marks a deliberate rejection. Signs point to the unique divinity and mission of Christ.

verses.text: But this happened in order to fulfill the word that is written in their Law: 'They hated me without a cause.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to Old Testament prophecy fulfilled by His rejection, reaffirming His messianic identity and divine plan.

verses.text: When the Helper comes, whom I will send to you from the Father—the Spirit of truth who proceeds from the Father—He will bear witness about me.
verses.comment: Jesus describes the coming of the Holy Spirit, identifying the Spirit’s personal mission and divine origin. This highlights the unity and distinctness in the Godhead, suggesting rich Trinitarian theology.

verses.text: And you also will bear witness, because you have been with me from the beginning.
verses.comment: The apostles’ direct experience with Jesus entrusts them with authoritative witness. This points toward the foundational apostolic tradition, which is vital for the continuity of the faith.
